quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Israel and Taj Mahal
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, leader, industries. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Does the Taj Mahal comprise four minarets?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Yes

questions.question: This is the year of the termination of the British mandate of Palestine and the signing of the Declaration of the Establishment of the State of Israel.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1948

questions.question: In which form of Israeli cooperative agricultural system, several farms agree to buy and use large machinery commonly?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Moshav

questions.question: In 1977, this Arab nation leader signed a peace agreement, known as the Camp David Accords with  Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Anwar Sadat

questions.question: This is one of the leading industries in Israel, as well as the most rapidly developing one.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: High technologies

questions.question: Did the Taj Mahal tomb have any jewels in it?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Yes

questions.question: Do visitors of the Taj Mahal have to take off their shoes before entering the building?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Yes

questions.question: About what percentage of Israels land of approximately 20,300 km² (7,849 mi²) is arable?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 17%

questions.question: Which group of countries includes Israel’s major international trading partners?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: USA, Belgium, Hong Kong, Germany

questions.question: What is the political system of Israel?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Parliamentary democracy

questions.question: How many workers were recruited to build the Taj Mahal?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: about 20,000 workers

questions.question: Where is the Taj Mahal located?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Agra

questions.question: The Taj Mahal is generally considered one of the seven wonders of the modern world.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: What was the Taj Mahal mainly made of?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: white granite

questions.question: In 1991, Israel was attacked and for the first time did not retaliate. Which country was the attacker?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Iraq

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Israel and Egypt
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, john, people. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: What fountain, sculpted by Thomas Waldo Story, features female figures and cherubs dancing next to a giant shell?

options.text: Artemis Fountain in Hyde Park, London
Тhe Fountain of Love in Cliveden
The Victoria Fountain in Old Steine, Brighton

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Тhe Fountain of Love in Cliveden

questions.question: These Victorian gardens in Staffordshire represent China, Egypt and a Scottish glen.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Biddulph Grange Garden

questions.question: It was on a hot summer day that the outside world descended on the small town of Dayton, Tennessee to see famed defense lawyer Clarence Darrow take on The Great Commoner William Jennings Bryan in what was known as The Monkey Trial. Who was the defendant?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Thomas Scopes

questions.question: The kidnapping and rape of a theater attendant on the night of March 3, 1963, while a very horrible deed, was to have far reaching consequence outside of the town of Phoenix, AZ.  In a case that went all the way to the Supreme Court of the U. S., this ruling was made to protect the ignorant and indigent but it applies to everyone when they are arrested. Who was the defendant in this landmark case in American Jurisprudence?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ernesto Miranda

questions.question: This house, situated in Westerham, Kent was bought by Winston Churchill in 1922.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Chartwell

questions.question: This simple farm house at the seaside was transformed into a palace for King George IV.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Royal Pavilion

questions.question: What Gothic building, regarded as a haunted place, is the burial site of Karl Marx?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Highgate Cemetery

questions.question: Only the little people pay taxes, declared the Queen of Mean. What lady faced charges of tax evasion, mail fraud, extortion and filing false tax returns for over 4 million dollars?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Leona Helmsley

questions.question: What happened to the Arabs living in Israel, after the Declaration of the Establishment of the State of Israel was signed?

options.text: All of them remained in the country.
They all left because of Israeli threats.
Some stayed in Israel, some sold their land and moved.
They all moved to the Gaza Strip.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Some stayed in Israel, some sold their land and moved.

questions.question: El Al, which is of major importance in Israel, is actually what kind of organization?

options.text: The national airline company of Israel

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The national airline company of Israel

questions.question: What is the birth place of Queen Victoria?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kensington Palace

questions.question: Julius and Ethel Rosenberg were found guilty of treason and electrocuted on June 19, 1953.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: John Gotti, head of the Gambino crime family in New York, was known as The Teflon Don because three times he was brought to trial and three times he walked. But in 1992 The Dapper Don was found guilty of violating the RICO law. Who was Gottis second in command that turned states witness and helped, with his testimony, bring down Gotti?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sammy the Bull Gravano

questions.question: This extraordinary church in Whitby, North Yorkshire inspired Bram Stoker to write his famous book Drakula.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: St Marys

questions.question: Which was the second country after Egypt to normalize its relations with Israel with a peace treaty of 1994?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jordan

quizzes.title: History Quiz: County and Seat
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, bridgeton, figures. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Of the following 4 civilizations which occupied Mesopotamia, which came first?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Akkadians

questions.question: Mays Landing is the county seat of Monmouth County.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Where did the Tour de France start in 2007?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Trafalgar Square

questions.question: A Gothic-styled memorial, which opened in 1872, included allegorical figures of Europe, Asia, Africa, and America and was made of granite and marble. It was erected in memory of this Royal person.

options.text: Prince Albert, husband of Queen Victoria

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Prince Albert, husband of Queen Victoria

questions.question: This county seat, known as the Silk City, is the home city to famous American actor and comedian Lou Costello.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Paterson

questions.question: Newton is the county seat of Sussex County.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: The unincorporated area of Toms River is the county seat of Warren County.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: What modern-day country includes most of ancient Mesopotamia?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Iraq

questions.question: Located in South Jersey, this county seat has a name related to a Hebrew word meaning peace.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Salem

questions.question: This county, formed in 1714, has Flemington as its county seat.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hunterdon County

questions.question: The Behistun Inscription was carved into a cliff wall. It was deciphered by Henry Rawlinson. It contains the same text in 3 different languages.  All 3 of the texts, however, are written in the same script. What is this script called?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cuneiform

questions.question: This coastal defence site was built on the Isle of Wight to protect Great Britain from French invasion.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Needles Old Battery

questions.question: Bridgeton, which has the largest historic district of any incorporated town in New Jersey, is the seat of which county?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cumberland County

questions.question: Out of the four original counties of East Jersey, which countys seat is Hackensack?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bergen County

questions.question: This county seat is known as The Military Capital of the Revolution, and contains sites like Fords Mansion and Jockey Hollow.  It was where George Washington encamped in the brutal winter of 1777.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Morristown

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Mountain and Mountain Range
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, peak, mean. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: How many meals a day did ancient Mesopotamians customarily eat?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 2

questions.question: During the reigns of which 2 Persian kings were invasions of Greece attempted?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Darius and Xerxes

questions.question: This mountain range is the longest on the planet, and is located in South America.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Andes

questions.question: This Babylonian ruler established written laws. His laws were one of the first written codes of law in recorded history.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hammurabi

questions.question: Which of the following pairings of ancient civilization and modern-day country is NOT CORRECT?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Phoenicians -- Egypt

questions.question: What two foods were the staples of the diet of the Sumerians?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Beer and Bread

questions.question: What does the Greek word mesopotamia mean?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Between two rivers

questions.question: This mountain contains the highest peak on the African continent.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kilimanjaro

questions.question: This mountain range is located in Eurasia between the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Caucasus Mountains

questions.question: This mountain range is located in Asia, its name means abode of snow, and it lies across the territory of six countries.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Himalayas

questions.question: This mountain range is located in Europe and its highest peak is Mont Blanc.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Alps

questions.question: The highest peak in North America is located in this mountain range.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Alaska Range

questions.question: Which king of the Akkadians conquered Sumeria to unite Mesopotamia under one ruler for the first time?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sargon

questions.question: This mountain contains the highest peak in Antarctica, and is located about 750 miles (1,200 km) from the South Pole.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Vinson Massif

questions.question: Zoroastrianism is a religion which originated with which ancient civilization?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Persians

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Toyota and Toyota Motor Corporation
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, headquarters, magazine. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: In 1959, this journalist, author of the acclaimed book Black Like Me, darkened his skin in an attempt to experience the segregation in the American South.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Howard Griffin

questions.question: Which Emmy Award winner invented CBS news magazine 60 Minutes in 1968?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Don Hewitt

questions.question: What is the highest mountain on the Australian mainland?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mount Kosciuszko

questions.question: In what mountain are the peaks Manaslu and Lhotse located?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Himalayas

questions.question: The Japanese multinational corporation Toyota Motor Corporation is the second largest automobile maker in the world for 2006 losing the first place to which company?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: General Motors

questions.question: Toyota’s T100, which was introduced in the 1990s, is what type of car?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: А full-size pickup

questions.question: Early Toyotas looked like a Dodge Powerwagon or a Chevrolet.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Although it is a leading automobile maker, what else does Toyota Motor Corporation produce beside automobiles?

options.text: Television sets and medical X-ray equipment

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Looms and sewing machines

questions.question: This mountain range is located in North America and its highest peak is Mount Mitchell.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Appalachians

questions.question: The top selling hybrid car for the U.S. of 2006 was produced by Toyota. Which one is it?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Toyota Prius

questions.question: Which famous U.S. magazine chose Albert Einstein as Person of the Century in 1999?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: TIME

questions.question: As the second largest automobile producer of 2006 for the United States, Toyota surpassed which company in the third place?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ford Motor Corporation

questions.question: Where is the headquarters of the Toyota Motor Corporation located?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Aichi, Japan

questions.question: What is Toyotas luxury car line called?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lexus

questions.question: In the 1970s what caused U.S. customers to become interested in companies like Toyota, Honda and Datsun (Nissan)?

options.text: The end of the Vietnam War
The distrust of Richard M. Nixon

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The 1973 oil crisis

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Term and Alaska
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, iditarod, bush. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This period, in which some newspapers and magazines built their reputations thanks to their use of photography, is known as the Golden Age of Photojournalism.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1930s-1950s

questions.question: What do Alaskan people call bunny boots?

options.text: Native boots crafted of rabbit fur

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Superinsulated boots

questions.question: In Alaskan terms, what is a snowbird?

options.text: A person who lives in Alaska in summer only

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A person who lives in Alaska in summer only

questions.question: Which CBS news show was the first to feature live simultaneous transmissions both from the East  Coast and the West  Coast?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: See It Now

questions.question: What does the term outside mean in Alaskan jargon?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Anywhere that is not Alaska

questions.question: In what year did the first Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race take place?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1973

questions.question: Which American newspaper won the 2002 Pulitzer Award for the coverage of the September 11 terrorist attacks on New York City?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Wall Street Journal

questions.question: Which journalist received the Pulitzer Prize in 1964 for his brilliant coverage of President John F. Kennedys assassination?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Merriman Smith

questions.question: The term bush refers to less populated areas of Alaska, not always accessible by roads.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: In Alaska, what term is used to refer to the contiguous states below Canada?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Lower 48

questions.question: Which is the United Kingdoms official newspaper first published on November 7, 1665?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The London Gazette

questions.question: Which weekly magazine, established in 1828 in London, had the same owner as The Daily Telegraph?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Spectator

questions.question: What does the Alaskan term break up mean?

options.text: An iceberg breaking into two pieces
End of winter, beginning of summer

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: End of winter, beginning of summer

questions.question: This American journalist, awarded the 2003 Gerald R. Ford Prize for Distinguished Reporting on the Presidency, took part in the uncovering of the Watergate scandal.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Robert Woodward

questions.question: The Iditarod Trail in Alaska was a sled dog mail route from Seward to Nome.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True
